Award.AwardTitle: Gromov-Witten theory under extremal transitions and birational transformations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gromov-Witten (GW) theory lies in the intersection of many exciting research areas in mathematics and physics. Roughly speaking it counts the number of curves meeting prescribed conditions in a geometric object called a variety. On the one hand, the theory itself has remarkable structures, both established and conjectural. Investigating these structures requires some new insights and technical tools from other areas. This provides a lot of interesting problems for classical subjects in mathematics. On the other hand, these new insights and technical tools help to discover deep relations and connections between existing mathematics and theoretical physics. This project will advance understanding in this active area of research. The project includes training of graduate students and postdocs, as well as international collaborations.

This research project lies on the intersection of algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. Specifically, it concerns the Gromov-Witten theory and variation of Hodge structures (VHS) on one side and birational geometry and mirror symmetry on the other. The main themes of the project are the study of GW theory of bundles and blowing-ups and the extended functoriality of GW and VHS under extremal transitions (also known as space-time topology change in the physics literature). The relations between the crepant transformation conjecture in GW theory and the Landau-Ginzburg / Calabi-Yau correspondence will also be studied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main activities supported by this grant is the research performed by the PI and his students, and the training of the graduate students. It consists of continuation and further generalization of our previous projects.

Gromov--Witten theory is a mathematical subject which has its origin in both mathematics and physics. It lies in the intersection of physics and many branches of mathematics, in particular algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry, representation theory, partial differential equations and integrable systems. Its practitioners consist of both mathematicians and string theorists. Therefore, the study of Gromov--Witten theory often finds new and interesting connections between previous unrelated topics in mathematics and physics.

This proposal studies various aspects of Gromov--Witten theory, but places particular emphasis on the naturality or functoriality problem of Gromov--Witten theory. In particular it explores and gets basic results to the following questions: How does Gromov--Witten theory of a space change when the space changes? What is the most natural way to describe the changes? How precisely can we describe the changes? These questions are central to our understanding of the geometry of the spaces, but prove very hard to answer. One of the reason of their difficulty is that Gromov--Witten theory packs a lot of highly nontrival information into the very definition of the theory. Any small change in the space can affect the theory in drastic ways. There are, however, ways to repackage these "drastic changes" so that they are recognizable and predictable. Through the efforts of our group and other groups, we now know much more than we did before. 

By its very definition, Gromov--Witten theory is deformation invariant. Previously, we already knew that when the spaces changes in a certain controlled way (called crepant transformation or K-equivalence), certain functions associated to the spaces will exhibit good properties (they are analytic function) and are closely related (via analytic continuation). On the one hand, we were able to generalize the applicability and improve their predications in this direction. On the other hand, we also seek to extend them beyond crepant transformation.

This proposal also provides training grounds for many excellent PhD students who wish to enter this exciting area of research and for young postdocs who wish to advance their research career. The students have been supported to conduct their research and to visit other universities and conferences to learn new techniques. Since our approach involves many advanced techniques and discovers many new phenomena which then generate new problems, these students and postdocs have been trained to master some of these difficult techniques and gone on to successful careers in research and teaching in mathematics.

All results obtained in this proposal are posted online and accessible to the public.
